analyzed: kukkuṭāḥ yasya rakta akṣāḥ sa me skandaḥ prasīdatu
translated: Whose cocks have red eyes, may that Skanda be gracious to me.

original: āgneyaṃ kṛttikāputram aindraṃ ke cid adhīyate /
analyzed: āgneyam kṛttikā putram aindram ke cit adhīyate
translated: Some consider him to be born of Agni, the son of the Krittikas, some to be born of Indra,

original: ke cit pāśupataṃ raudraṃ yo 'si so 'si namo 'stu ta iti //
analyzed: ke cit pāśupatam raudram yaḥ si saḥ si namaḥ stu te iti
translated: Some to be born of Pasupati, Rudra, whatever you are, salutations to you.

analyzed: svāmine namaḥ śaṅkarāya agni putrāya kṛttikā putrāya namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the Lord, to Shankara, to the son of Agni, to the son of Krittika.

original: bhagavān kva cid apratirūpaḥ svāhā bhagavān kva cid apratirūpaḥ //🔽maṇiratnavarapratirūpaḥ //
analyzed: bhagavān kva cit apratirūpaḥ svāhā bhagavān kva cit apratirūpaḥ
translated: The Blessed One is sometimes of incomparable form, the Blessed One is sometimes of incomparable form.🔽He is of the form of the best gem jewel.

analyzed: kāñcana ratna vara pratirūpaḥ iti
translated: He is of the form of the best gold jewel.

original: ete te deva gandhā etāni puṣpāṇy eṣa dhūpa etāṃ mālāṃ triḥ pradakṣiṇāṃ kṛtvā ādityakartitaṃ sūtram iti pratisaram ābadhnīyāt
analyzed: ete te deva gandhāḥ etāni puṣpāṇi eṣa dhūpaḥ etām mālām tris pradakṣiṇām kṛtvā āditya kartitam sūtram iti pratisaram ābadhnīyāt
translated: O God, these are your fragrances, these are the flowers, this is the incense, having circumambulated three times, one should tie the thread cut by the sun, the counter-charm.

analyzed: āditya kartitam sūtram indreṇa trivṛtīkṛtam
translated: The thread cut by the sun, made threefold by Indra,

original: aśvibhyāṃ grathito granthir brahmaṇā pratisaraḥ kṛtaḥ //
analyzed: aśvibhyām grathitaḥ granthiḥ brahmaṇā pratisaraḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: the knot tied by the Ashvins, the counter-charm made by Brahma.

original: dhanyaṃ yaśasyam āyuṣyam aśubhasya ca ghātanam /
analyzed: dhanyam yaśasyam āyuṣyam aśubhasya ca ghātanam
translated: It is blessed, it brings fame and longevity, it destroys inauspiciousness.

original: badhnāmi pratisaram imaṃ sarvaśatrunibarhanam //🔽rakṣobhyaś ca piśācebhyo gandharvebhyas tathaiva ca /
analyzed: badhnāmi pratisaram imam sarva śatru nibarhanam  rakṣobhyaḥ ca piśācebhyaḥ gandharvebhyaḥ tathā eva ca
translated: I tie this counter-charm, which destroys all enemies.🔽There is no fear from rakshasas, pishachas, and gandharvas, and from humans,

original: manuṣyebhyo bhayaṃ nāsti yac ca syād duṣkṛtaṃ kṛtam //
analyzed: manuṣyebhyaḥ bhayam na asti yat ca syāt duṣkṛtam kṛtam
translated: and whatever bad deed may have been done.

analyzed: sva kṛtāt para kṛtāt ca duṣkṛtāt pratimucyate
translated: One is freed from bad deeds done by oneself or by others.

original: sarvasmāt pātakān mukto bhaved vīras tathaiva ca //
analyzed: sarvasmāt pātakāt muktaḥ bhavet vīraḥ tathā eva ca
translated: And the hero will be freed from all sins.

original: abhicārāc ca kṛtyātaḥ strīkṛtād aśubhaṃ ca yat /
analyzed: abhicārāt ca kṛtyātaḥ strī kṛtāt aśubham ca yat
translated: And from sorcery, from witchcraft, and from the inauspicious done by women,

original: tāvat tasya bhataṃ nāsti yāvat sūtraṃ sa dhārayet //
analyzed: tāvat tasya bhatam na asti yāvat sūtram sa dhārayet
translated: As long as he upholds the sutra, he will have no fear.

original: yāvad āpaś ca gāvaś ca yāvat sthāsyanti parvatāḥ /
analyzed: yāvat āpaḥ ca gāvaḥ ca yāvat sthāsyanti parvatāḥ
translated: As long as the waters and the cows remain, as long as the mountains stand,

original: tāvat tasya bhayaṃ nāsti yaḥ sūtraṃ dhārayiṣyatīti //
analyzed: tāvat tasya bhayam na asti yaḥ sūtram dhārayiṣyati iti
translated: For that long, he who will uphold the sutra has no fear.

analyzed: anvāyam bhuktvā devam visarjayet
translated: Having recited this, one should dismiss the god.

analyzed: pramodaḥ nāma gandharvaḥ paridhāvati
translated: The gandharva named Pramoda runs at dusk,

original: muñca śailamayāt pāpan muñcamuñca pramuñca ca //
analyzed: muñca śaila mayāt pāpan muñca muñca pramuñca ca
translated: Release me from the sin of the mountain, release, release, and let go.

original: yāvat imā āpaḥ pavanena pūtā hiraṇyavarṇā anavadyarūpāḥ /
analyzed: yāvat imāḥ āpaḥ pavanena pūtāḥ hiraṇya varṇāḥ anavadya rūpāḥ
translated: As long as these waters are purified by the wind, golden-colored, of irreproachable form,

original: tāvad imaṃ dhūrtaṃ pravāhayāmi pravāhito me dehi varān yathoktān //
analyzed: tāvat imam dhūrtam pravāhayāmi pravāhitaḥ me dehi varān yathā uktān
translated: For that long, I will carry away this cheat. Having been carried away, give me the boons as stated.

original: uditeṣu nakṣatreṣu gṛhān praviṣṭo gṛhiṇīṃ paśyet dhanavati dhanaṃ me dehīti //
analyzed: uditeṣu nakṣatreṣu gṛhān praviṣṭaḥ gṛhiṇīm paśyet dhanavati dhanam me dehi iti
translated: When the stars have risen and he has entered the house, he should see his wife and say, In your wealth, give me wealth.

original: yad bhoktuṃ kāmajātaṃ jagatyāṃ manasā saṃhīhate tattad dvijanmā pinākasenayajamānāt kāmam upabhukto bhuktvāmṛtatvaṃ tadvad
analyzed: yat bhoktum kāma jātam jagatyām manasā tat tat dvijanmā pinākasena yajamānāt kāmam upabhuktaḥ bhuktvā amṛta tvam tadvat
translated: Whatever is desired to be enjoyed in the world by the mind, that is enjoyed by the twice-born, by the sacrificer of the Pinaka-wielding Shiva, just as nectar is enjoyed.

analyzed: eva abhyupaiti
translated: Whatever is desired to be enjoyed in the world by the mind, that is enjoyed by the twice-born, by the sacrificer of Pināka-sena, from desire, having enjoyed it, he attains immortality like that.

analyzed: saṃbhāra lakṣaṇam
translated: The definition of requisites

analyzed: om saṃbhārān kīrtayiṣyāmaḥ yathā lakṣaṇa saṃyutān
translated: Om. We shall proclaim the requisites along with their characteristics,

original: yaiḥ karma kriyamāṇaṃ hi phalavat syād dvijanmanām //
analyzed: yaiḥ karma kriyamāṇam hi phalavat syāt dvijanmanām
translated: By which the act being performed becomes fruitful for the twice-born.

analyzed: a chinna agrān kuśān ārdrān indranīla sama prabhān
translated: The Kusha grass should be unbroken at the tips, moist, and having the lustre of sapphire,

original: śuṣkān api śvetavarṇān āhuḥ śāntikarān budhāḥ //
analyzed: śuṣkān api śveta varṇān āhuḥ śānti karān budhāḥ
translated: Even the dry ones should be white in color, the wise say they bring about peace.

original: surabhīṇi ca puṣpāṇi susvādūni phalāni ca manoharāṇi vāsāṃsi saṃbhāreṣūpakalpayet //
analyzed: surabhīṇi ca puṣpāṇi su svādūni phalāni ca manoharāṇi vāsāṃsi saṃbhāreṣu upakalpayet
translated: One should arrange fragrant flowers, very tasty fruits, and charming garments in the requisites.

original: surabhīṇy eva bījāni anyavastūni yāni ca /
analyzed: surabhīṇi eva bījāni anya vastūni yāni ca
translated: Fragrant seeds and other objects,

analyzed: argha candana dhūpa ādi hema ratna ādi ca uttamam
translated: Arghya, sandalwood, incense, etc., gold, gems, etc., which are excellent,

original: gāvaś ca dakṣiṇārthaṃ hi payasvinyaḥ sulakṣaṇāḥ /
analyzed: gāvaḥ ca dakṣiṇā artham hi payasvinyaḥ su lakṣaṇāḥ
translated: And cows with good characteristics, which are milch cows, for the sake of Dakshina,

analyzed: ṣoḍaśa aṣṭau ca catvāraḥ caturṇām veda vittamāḥ
translated: The best among the knowers of the four Vedas, sixteen, eight, and four,

analyzed: ṛtvijaḥ tu samākhyātāḥ vayaḥ śīla guṇa anvitāḥ
translated: The priests are declared to be endowed with age, character, and good qualities.

analyzed: dvātriṃśat ṣoḍaśa aṣṭau vā śānti kārye tathā adbhute
translated: thirty-two, sixteen or eight, in the case of peace-making rites and also in the case of prodigies.

analyzed: sa hiraṇyāḥ sa vastrāḥ ca sa alaṃkārāḥ sa vatsakāḥ
translated: Along with gold, garments, ornaments, and calves,

original: te sadasyā iti proktā vācane yajñakarmaṇi //
analyzed: te sadasyāḥ iti proktāḥ vācane yajña karmaṇi
translated: they are said to be the members of the assembly in the recitation of the sacrificial rites.

original: sarve te 'pi hy atharvāṇa ṛtvijaḥ ṣoḍaśa smṛtāḥ /
analyzed: sarve te hi atharvāṇaḥ ṛtvijaḥ ṣoḍaśa smṛtāḥ
translated: All of them are also considered to be Atharvan priests, sixteen in number.

original: śuddhātmāno japair homair vaidikair vītamatsarāḥ //🔽tāmrarājatahaimānāṃ mṛnmayānām athāpi vā /
analyzed: śuddha ātmānaḥ japaiḥ homaiḥ vaidikaiḥ vīta matsarāḥ  tāmra rājata haimānām mṛd mayānām atha api vā
translated: They are pure-souled, free from envy, and perform Vedic japa and homa.🔽The collection of flawless, unpunctured, and uncracked pots made of copper, silver, gold, or clay,

original: achidrāṇāṃ savarṇānāṃ kalaśānāṃ ca saṃgrahaḥ //🔽carūṇām atha pātrāṇām indhanānāṃ viśeṣataḥ /
analyzed: achidrāṇām savarṇānām kalaśānām ca saṃgrahaḥ  carūṇām atha pātrāṇām indhanānām viśeṣataḥ
translated: of the same color,

analyzed: yava vrīhi tila ādīnām ājyasya āharaṇam tathā
translated: of sacrificial ladles, of vessels for the oblations, and especially of fuel,🔽and also of barley, rice, sesame seeds, etc., and of ghee,

original: achidrāsphātitāvakrā dīrghaparvāḥ sumadhyamāḥ /🔽śamīdūrvātarūṇāṃ tu jñeyāḥ śāntau śabhāvāḥ //
analyzed: achidra āsphātita avakrāḥ dīrgha parvāḥ su madhyamāḥ  śamī dūrvā tarūṇām tu jñeyāḥ śāntau śa bhāvāḥ
translated: flawless, not inflated, not crooked, with long joints, and a good middle,🔽of shami, durva grass, and trees, should be known as auspicious for peace-making.

analyzed: puṣkara tantu go vāla truṭi sarṣapa yavasya tu
translated: The hair of a cow's tail, a cow's tail, mustard, and barley,

original: ṣaḍguṇitaḥṣaḍguṇito bhavati narasyāṅgulamāne //🔽gopucchasadṛśo daṇḍaḥ samaḥ ślakṣṇo manoharaḥ /
analyzed: ṣaṣ guṇitaḥ ṣaṣ guṇitaḥ bhavati narasya aṅgula māne  go puccha sadṛśaḥ daṇḍaḥ samaḥ ślakṣṇaḥ manoharaḥ
translated: are six times the measure of a man's finger.🔽The sacrificial ladle should be known to be like a cow's tail, even, smooth, and pleasing to the mind.

original: sruvaś ca śāntuke jñeyaḥ srug uktā yajñalakṣaṇā //
analyzed: sruvaḥ ca śāntuke jñeyaḥ sruc uktā yajña lakṣaṇā
translated: The sacrificial ladle is said to be the characteristic of a sacrifice.

original: sauvarṇaḥ śāntike proktaḥ pālaśo vātha khādiraḥ /🔽abhicāre viśeṣeṇa kuryāt sruvam ayomayam //
analyzed: sauvarṇaḥ śāntike proktaḥ pālaśaḥ vā atha khādiraḥ  abhicāre viśeṣeṇa kuryāt sruvam ayaḥ mayam
translated: A golden one is prescribed for peace, or one made of palasha wood or khadira wood.🔽For black magic, one should especially make the ladle of iron.

analyzed: kāṃsyam yat ca aṭane kuryāt āśvattham vaśya karmaṇi
translated: For exorcism, one should make it of bronze, and for subjugation, of ashvattha wood.

original: viśeṣeṇa tu vidveṣe sruvo nimbamayaḥ smṛtaḥ //🔽pauṣṭike rājataṃ vidyāt tāmraṃ ca vijayāvaham /
analyzed: viśeṣeṇa tu vidveṣe sruvaḥ nimba mayaḥ smṛtaḥ  pauṣṭike rājatam vidyāt tāmram ca vijaya āvaham
translated: For enmity in particular, a ladle made of neem wood is remembered.🔽For nourishment, one should know it to be made of silver, and copper brings victory.

original: amṛtādau tu vijñeyaś cāndanaḥ siddhidaḥ sruvaḥ //
translated: For Amrita and other [rites], the ladle made of sandalwood should be known to bestow success.

original: sruvāṇāṃ viṣayaṃ jñātvā kīlakānāṃ vidhiṃ tathā /
analyzed: sruvāṇām viṣayam jñātvā kīlakānām vidhim tathā
translated: Knowing the domain of ladles and the procedure of stakes,

analyzed: gṛhasya aśma vidhim dikṣu karma siddhim avāpnuyāt
translated: and the procedure of stones in the directions of the house, one will attain success in the rites.🔽In a place free from sleshmataka, arka, kantakarika, pungent, bitter, and other [plants],

original: ariṣṭagṛdhrakauśikavihaṃgaiś ca vivarjite //🔽gulmavallīlatāyukte hṛdyaiś ca madhurair drumaiḥ /
analyzed: ariṣṭa gṛdhra kauśika vihaṃgaiḥ ca vivarjite  gulma vallī latā yukte hṛdyaiḥ ca madhuraiḥ drumaiḥ
translated: free from inauspicious, vulture, owl, and other birds,🔽endowed with shrubs, creepers, and vines, and with pleasant and sweet trees,

analyzed: taruṇaiḥ phalavadbhiḥ ca śmaśāna asthi vivarjite  mayūra cakravāka ādi haṃsa kāraṇḍava ādibhiḥ
translated: with young and fruit-bearing trees, free from cremation grounds and bones,

analyzed: su svaraiḥ nādite deśe hṛdya aṅkura samanvite
translated: in a place resounding with the sweet sounds of peacocks, ruddy geese, and other birds, swans, karandavas, and other birds,🔽endowed with pleasant sprouts,

analyzed: nadī taṭe samudrasya saṃgame vā viśeṣataḥ
translated: on the bank of a river, or especially at the confluence of a river and the ocean,

original: anindye digvibhāge ca uttare vāparājite //🔽bhūmiṃ saṃśodhayet kartā prāgudakppravaṇe śubhe /
analyzed: anindye diś vibhāge ca uttare vā aparājite  bhūmim saṃśodhayet kartā śubhe
translated: In the northern direction, which is faultless and unconquered.🔽The performer should clear the ground on an auspicious slope towards the northeast.

original: prācīṃ saṃśodhya yatnena maṇḍapaṃ tatra kārayet //
analyzed: prācīm saṃśodhya yatnena maṇḍapam tatra kārayet
translated: Having carefully cleared the east, he should build a pavilion there.

original: navakoṣṭhaṃ samaṃ vāpi hastaiḥ ṣoṣaśabhir mitam /
analyzed: nava koṣṭham samam vā api hastaiḥ ṣoṣaśabhiḥ mitam
translated: Nine chambers or equal, measured with sixty-four handspans,

analyzed: caturaśram catur dvāram eka ūrdhva dvāram eva vā
translated: Square, with four doors, or with one door above.

analyzed: tatas īśāna koṇe tu snāna vedim samācaret
translated: Then, in the northeast corner, he should make a bathing altar,

analyzed: daśa dvādaśa hastam vā yathāvitānam eva vā
translated: Ten or twelve cubits long, or according to the size of the canopy.

original: caturguṇocchrayāś caiva mūlastambhās tu ye tataḥ /
analyzed: caturguṇa ucchrayāḥ ca eva mūla stambhāḥ tu ye tatas
translated: The main pillars should be four times as high as that,

original: upastambhās tu ye pārśve tadardhena prakīrtitāḥ //
analyzed: upastambhāḥ tu ye pārśve tad ardhena prakīrtitāḥ
translated: And the side pillars are proclaimed to be half of that.

original: kumbhāḥ stambhais tathā deyāḥ kāmair dvāraṃ diśāṃ smṛtam /
analyzed: kumbhāḥ stambhaiḥ tathā deyāḥ kāmaiḥ dvāram diśām smṛtam
translated: The pitchers should be given according to the pillars, and the door in the directions is remembered to be with desires.

analyzed: yajamāna ucchrayam vā api tad ardhena prakīrtitāḥ
translated: Or the height of the sacrificer, or half of that is proclaimed.

analyzed: kuṇḍa ākṛti gṛham kuryāt dviguṇam pariveṣtitam
translated: The house should be made in the shape of a pit, twice as large in circumference.

original: sarvadikṣu plavaṃ caiva kuṇḍasyordhvaṃ na chādayet //
analyzed: sarva dikṣu plavam ca eva kuṇḍasya ūrdhvam na chādayet
translated: All around, and floating in all directions, one should not cover above the pit.

analyzed: paritas dvādaśa sthūnam catur stambham tu madhyatas
translated: With twelve pillars all around, and four pillars in the middle,

original: arcitaṃ pūjitaṃ nityaṃ śāntau śāntigṛhaṃ smṛtam //
analyzed: arcitam pūjitam nityam śāntau śānti gṛham smṛtam
translated: Worshipped and always honoured, it is remembered as the house of peace in peace.

analyzed: netra ādi ulloca śobhiṣṭham nānā varṇa dhvaja ākulam
translated: Most beautiful with the twinkling of eyes and so on, crowded with flags of various colours.

original: raktā pītā ca dhūmrā ca kṛṣṇā nīlātha pāṇḍurā //
analyzed: raktā pītā ca dhūmrā ca kṛṣṇā nīlā atha pāṇḍurā
translated: Red, yellow, smoky, black, blue, and white,

analyzed: vicitrā hi indranīla ābhā patākāḥ ṣoḍaśa smṛtāḥ
translated: The flags are remembered as sixteen in number, with various colours like sapphire.

analyzed: aindrāyudha dhūmra kṛṣṇa nīla pāṇḍura varṇakāḥ
translated: Having the colours of the rainbow, smoky, black, blue, white,

analyzed: pīta rakta sitāḥ śyāmā patākāḥ ṣoḍaśa smṛtāḥ
translated: Yellow, red, white, and dark, the flags are remembered as sixteen in number.

analyzed: kalaśān ṣoḍaśān tatra upariṣṭāt mahā dhvajaḥ
translated: There, above the sixteen water pots, is the great flag.

analyzed: vastreṇa āchāditān kuryāt sa hiraṇyān pṛthak pṛthak
translated: They should be covered with cloth, each with gold,

original: maṇimuktāphalaiḥ puṣpair hṛdyaiś ca madhuraiḥ phalaiḥ //
analyzed: maṇi muktāphalaiḥ puṣpaiḥ hṛdyaiḥ ca madhuraiḥ phalaiḥ
translated: With jewels, pearls, flowers, and pleasing sweet fruits,

original: samantād dikṣu vinyastaiḥ pradīpaiś cāpy alaṃkṛtam /🔽dhūpair balyupahāraiś ca jayaghoṣaiś ca bandinām //
analyzed: samantāt dikṣu vinyastaiḥ pradīpaiḥ ca api alaṃkṛtam  dhūpaiḥ bali upahāraiḥ ca jaya ghoṣaiḥ ca bandinām
translated: Adorned all around with directions and placed lamps.🔽With incense, offerings, and shouts of victory from bards,

analyzed: śaṅkha tūrya ninādaiḥ tu vīṇā dundubhi sa smitaiḥ
translated: With the sounds of conch shells, trumpets, veenas, and drums,

analyzed: pūjyamānaḥ hi nṛpatiḥ praviśet sa purohitaḥ
translated: The king, being worshipped, should enter with the priest.

analyzed: tatas śāntyudakam kṛtvā cātanena anuyojitam
translated: Then, having performed the water of peace, accompanied by the exorcism,

original: saṃprokṣya vidhivan mantrair ānayed araṇī tataḥ //🔽mathite 'gnau vidhānena śāntyudakena samantrakam /
analyzed: saṃprokṣya vidhivat mantraiḥ ānayet araṇī tatas  mathite gnau vidhānena śāntyudakena sa mantrakam
translated: Having sprinkled it with water as per procedure with mantras, one should bring the kindling sticks.

original: homaṃ kṛtvā yathoktaṃ tu nimittāny upalakṣayet //
analyzed: homam kṛtvā yathoktam tu nimittāni upalakṣayet
translated: In the churned fire, having performed the homa with the water of pacification along with mantras as per procedure, one should observe the omens as stated.

analyzed: megha dundubhi nirghoṣaiḥ prajvalan sarvatas tathā
translated: If the fire blazes everywhere with the sounds of clouds and drums,
with uninterrupted long flames and very glossy, it brings about success.

analyzed: kiṃśuka aśoka padma ābhaḥ nīlotpala nibhaḥ tathā
translated: If the fire has the color of kimshuka, ashoka, or lotus, or the color of blue lotus,

original: vahniḥ siddhikaro jñeyaḥ saptarātrān na saṃśayaḥ //
analyzed: vahniḥ siddhi karaḥ jñeyaḥ sapta rātrāt na saṃśayaḥ
translated: one should know that such a fire brings about success within seven nights, there is no doubt.

analyzed: huta mātre prajvalati vihasan iva dṛśyate
translated: If the fire blazes forth as soon as the oblation is offered, as if laughing,

original: taṃ vidyāt siddhidaṃ vahniṃ padmavarṇanibhaṃ tathā //
analyzed: tam vidyāt siddhi dam vahnim padma varṇa nibham tathā
translated: one should know that such a fire, having the color of a lotus, bestows success.

original: asnigdhārciḥ sadhūmo yaḥ kṛṣṇavarṇo 'pradakṣiṇaḥ /🔽yathoktaviparītas tu na vahniḥ syāt prayaṃkaraḥ //
analyzed: a snigdha arciḥ sa dhūmaḥ yaḥ kṛṣṇa varṇo pradakṣiṇaḥ  yathā ukta viparītaḥ tu na vahniḥ syāt
translated: If the flames are not glossy, there is smoke, the color is black, and it does not move clockwise,🔽such a fire, contrary to what is stated, does not bring about prosperity.

analyzed: yasmin prasanna tām eti hūyamāne hutāśane
translated: If the sacrificial fire becomes tranquil when oblations are offered,

original: tatra nityaṃ mahāsiddhir asamāpte vinirdiśet //🔽asamāpte vinirdiśet //🔽iti saṃbhāralakṣaṇaṃ samāptam //🔽araṇilakṣaṇam
analyzed: tatra nityam mahāsiddhiḥ asamāpte vinirdiśet 🔽a samāpte vinirdiśet 🔽iti saṃbhāra lakṣaṇam samāptam 🔽araṇi lakṣaṇam
translated: one should always predict great success even before the completion of the rite.

original: om athātaḥ saṃpravakṣyāmi araṇyoś caiva lakṣaṇam /
analyzed: om atha atas saṃpravakṣyāmi araṇyoḥ ca eva lakṣaṇam
translated: Om. Now I shall explain the characteristics of the two kinds of sacrificial fires,

original: rūpam athā pramāṇaṃ ca guṇadoṣān tathaiva ca //
analyzed: rūpam athā pramāṇam ca guṇa doṣān tathā eva ca
translated: their form, size, qualities and faults,

analyzed: coditān śabda śāstreṇa ācāryeṇa tu dhīmatā
translated: as prescribed by the wise teacher in the science of sound,

original: purā kalpe ca yad dṛṣṭam ṛṣibhiś caiva lakṣaṇam //
analyzed: purā kalpe ca yat dṛṣṭam ṛṣibhiḥ ca eva lakṣaṇam
translated: and the characteristics seen by the sages in the past Kalpa.

analyzed: gṛhya agnim parisaṃgṛhya dharma patnyā saha eva tu
translated: Having collected the domestic fire, together with the wife of Dharma,

analyzed: vaitānikāḥ tatas kuryāt ādhāna ādyāḥ yathā uditāḥ
translated: one should then perform the Vedic rites beginning with the establishment of the sacrificial fires, as prescribed.

original: tithau śubhāyāṃ nakṣatre diśaṃ gatvā tv aninditām /
analyzed: tithau śubhāyām nakṣatre diśam gatvā tu aninditām
translated: On an auspicious lunar day and constellation, having gone to an uncensured direction,

original: aśvatthāt tu śamīgarbhād uktam āharaṇaṃ śruteḥ //
analyzed: aśvatthāt tu śamīgarbhāt uktam āharaṇam śruteḥ
translated: the extraction from the fig tree in the heart of the shami tree is mentioned in the scriptures.

analyzed: śamī vṛkṣe tu śvatthaḥ na anya vṛkṣeṇa saṃyutaḥ
translated: The fig tree in the shami tree, not connected with any other tree,

original: madhye mūlaṃ na bāhye tu sa garbhaḥ parikīrtitaḥ //🔽abhāve tu śamīgarbhe aśvatthād eva vāharet /
analyzed: madhye mūlam na bāhye tu sa garbhaḥ parikīrtitaḥ  abhāve tu śamīgarbhe aśvatthāt eva vā āharet
translated: the middle root, not the outer one, is declared to be the heart.🔽In the absence of the heart of the shami tree, one should extract it from the fig tree itself.

original: prāpte caiva śamīgarbhe samāropya visarjayet //🔽caturviṃśāṅgulā dīrghā vistareṇa ṣaḍaṅgulā /
analyzed: prāpte ca eva śamīgarbhe samāropya visarjayet  caturviṃśa aṅgulā dīrghā vistareṇa ṣaṣ aṅgulā
translated: When the heart of the shami tree is obtained, having placed it on the fig tree, one should release it.🔽Twenty-four fingers long, six fingers wide,

analyzed: catur aṅgula ucchrayā ca araṇiḥ ca uttarāraṇiḥ
translated: four fingers high, is the lower kindling wood and the upper kindling wood.

original: ā skandhād uraso vāpi iti staudāyanaiḥ smṛtā /
analyzed: ā skandhāt urasaḥ vā api iti staudāyanaiḥ smṛtā
translated: Up to the shoulder or chest - this is remembered by the Sthaudayana school.

analyzed: bāhu mātrā devadarśaiḥ jājalaiḥ ūru mātrikā
translated: Up to the arm by the Devadarsha school, up to the thigh by the Jajala school.

analyzed: cāraṇa vaidyaiḥ jaṅghe ca maudena aṣṭa aṅgulāni ca
translated: Up to the calf by the Charana and Vaidya schools, eight fingers by the Maudena school.

original: jaladāyanair vitastir vā ṣoḍaśeti tu bhārgavaḥ //🔽śiraḥpramāṇe nābhau tu caturviṃśatikaiva hi /
analyzed: jalada ayanaiḥ vitastiḥ vā ṣoḍaśa iti tu bhārgavaḥ  śiraḥ pramāṇe nābhau tu caturviṃśatikā eva hi
translated: Up to the width of a span by the Jalaayana school, sixteen by the Bhargava school.

original: śaunakādibhir ācāryair etan mānaṃ prakīrtitam //🔽tasyās tu piṇḍaḥ ṣaḍbhāge caturbhāge tu vistare /
analyzed: śaunaka ādibhiḥ ācāryaiḥ etat mānam prakīrtitam  tasyāḥ tu piṇḍaḥ ṣaṣ bhāge catur bhāge tu vistare
translated: Only twenty-four fingers at the navel, which is the measure of the head - this is declared by the teachers beginning with Shaunaka.🔽Her lump should be in the sixth part, and the width in the fourth part.

analyzed: caturaśrā ca ślakṣṇā ca chidra granthi vivarjitā
translated: It should be square, smooth, free from holes and knots.

analyzed: klinnā bhinna agni saṃspṛṣṭā sphuṭitā vidyutā hatā
translated: Wet, broken, burnt, cracked, struck by lightning,

original: anyaiś ca doṣaiḥ saṃyuktā varjanīyā prayatnataḥ //
analyzed: anyaiḥ ca doṣaiḥ saṃyuktā varjanīyā prayatnataḥ
translated: and associated with other defects, it should be carefully avoided.

analyzed: śiraḥ granthiḥ haret cakṣuḥ chidrā patnī vināśinī
translated: A knot on the head would take away the eyes, a hole would destroy the wife,

original: klinnā vināśayet putrān sphuṭitā śokam āvahet //
analyzed: klinnā vināśayet putrān sphuṭitā śokam āvahet
translated: a wet one would destroy the sons, and a cracked one would bring grief.

original: ūrdhvaśuṣke na kartavyā kṛṣṇe rūkṣe tathaiva ca /
analyzed: ūrdhva śuṣke na kartavyā kṛṣṇe rūkṣe tathā eva ca
translated: It should not be done if it is dry above, black, or rough,

original: ubhe apy ekavṛkṣe ca araṇiś cottarāraṇiḥ //
analyzed: ubhe api eka vṛkṣe ca araṇiḥ ca uttarāraṇiḥ
translated: or if both are on the same tree, or if it is the churning stick or the upper churning stick.

original: tatpramāṇā tadardhā vā bhūyasī vā yathecchayā /
analyzed: tad pramāṇā tad ardhā vā bhūyasī vā yathā icchayā
translated: It should be of that measure or half of that or more, as desired.

original: anenaiva tu manthavyo na kuryād yonisaṃkaram //
analyzed: anena eva tu manthavyaḥ na kuryāt yoni saṃkaram
translated: But it should be churned with this alone. One should not mix the wombs.

analyzed: yoni saṃkara saṃkīrṇe mahān doṣaḥ prapadyate
translated: In the mixed and confused wombs, a great fault arises.

original: sa yajñas tāmaso nāma phalaṃ tatra na vidyate //🔽piṇḍe tv ayanaviṣuvau pṛthutve ṛtavaḥ sthitāḥ /
analyzed: sa yajñaḥ tāmasaḥ nāma phalam tatra na vidyate  piṇḍe tu ayana viṣuvau pṛthu tve ṛtavaḥ sthitāḥ
translated: That sacrifice is called tamas, and there is no fruit there.🔽In the ball, the equinoctial points and solstices are situated in the breadth,

original: ardhamāsāś ca dīrghatve kālaś cātra pratiṣṭhitaḥ //
analyzed: ardha māsāḥ ca dīrgha tve kālaḥ ca atra pratiṣṭhitaḥ
translated: and the fortnights in the length, and time is established here.

analyzed: yajamānaḥ raṇiḥ iti vadanti eke vipaścitaḥ
translated: Some wise ones say that the sacrificer is the churning stick.

original: tatpradhānāḥ kriyāḥ sarvā yajñaś cāpi tathaiva hi //
analyzed: tad pradhānāḥ kriyāḥ sarvāḥ yajñaḥ ca api tathā eva hi
translated: All actions are mainly based on that, and the sacrifice is also like that.

analyzed: prathame mūla ṣaḍbhāge pādau jaṅghā iti kīrtyate
translated: In the first one-sixth of the root, the feet and shanks are declared.

original: dvitīye jānunī ūrū tṛtīye śroṇir ucyate //
analyzed: dvitīye jānunī ūrū tṛtīye śroṇiḥ ucyate
translated: In the second, the knees and thighs are said, and in the third, the pelvis.

original: caturthe jaṭharaṃ sāṅgaṃ grīvā caiva tu pañcame /
analyzed: caturthe jaṭharam sa aṅgam grīvā ca eva tu pañcame
translated: In the fourth, the belly with its limbs, and in the fifth, the neck.

original: ṣaṣthe śiraḥ samākhyātam aṅgāny etāni nirdiśet //
analyzed: ṣaṣthe śiraḥ samākhyātam aṅgāni etāni nirdiśet
translated: In the sixth, the head is declared. These are the limbs that should be indicated.

analyzed: mathite pāda jaṅghe ca piśācaḥ saṃprajāyate
translated: When churned, if the feet and shanks are cut, a ghost is born.

original: jānunoś ca tathā corvo rākṣastvaṃ prayāti hi //
analyzed: jānunoḥ ca tathā ca ūrvaḥ rākṣaḥ tvam prayāti hi
translated: And if the knees and thighs are cut, one goes to the state of a rakshasa.

original: śroṇyāṃ ca sarvakāmāḥ syur jaṭhare kṣut tathā smṛtā /
analyzed: śroṇyām ca sarva kāmāḥ syuḥ jaṭhare kṣudh tathā smṛtā
translated: All desires should be in the hips, and hunger is remembered in the belly.

original: urasy amitrā grīvāyāṃ mṛtyuḥ śirasi vedanā //
analyzed: urasi amitrāḥ grīvāyām mṛtyuḥ śirasi vedanā
translated: Enemies are in the chest, and death is in the neck, and pain is in the head.

original: śroṇyām evāta aicchanti nirdoṣā kīrtitā yataḥ /
analyzed: śroṇyām eva atas aicchanti nirdoṣā kīrtitā yatas
translated: Therefore, they desire only in the hips, as it is declared to be faultless.

original: tathā vittapaśūn putrān svargam āyuḥ priyaṃ sukham //
analyzed: tathā vitta paśūn putrān svargam āyuḥ priyam sukham
translated: Similarly, wealth, cattle, sons, heaven, long life, what is dear, and happiness,

original: prathamaṃ manthanaṃ śroṇyām ādhāne ca viśeṣataḥ /
analyzed: prathamam manthanam śroṇyām ādhāne ca viśeṣataḥ
translated: The first churning is in the hips, and especially in the installation.

original: itarāṇi yatheṣtaṃ hi grīvāṃ sarvatra varjayet //
analyzed: itarāṇi yatheṣtam hi grīvām sarvatra varjayet
translated: The others are as desired, but one should always avoid the neck.

original: trīṇy aṅgulāni tyaktvādau tathā catvāri cāntataḥ /
analyzed: trīṇi aṅgulāni tyaktvā ādau tathā catvāri ca antatas
translated: Having left three fingers at the beginning, and four at the end,

original: madhye devāḥ sthitās tasmād vahniṃ tatraiva manthayet //
analyzed: madhye devāḥ sthitāḥ tasmāt vahnim tatra eva manthayet
translated: The gods are situated in the middle, therefore one should churn the fire there itself.

original: anulomā bhaved yoniḥ pārśvabhedo na vidyate /
analyzed: anulomā bhavet yoniḥ pārśvabhedaḥ na vidyate
translated: The womb should be in the direction of the gods, there should be no difference in the sides.

analyzed: ānulomyena mathitaḥ sarvān kāmān prayacchati
translated: Churned in the direction of the gods, it grants all desires.

original: mūlād aṅgulam utsṛjya trīṇitrīṇi ca pārśvayoḥ /
analyzed: mūlāt aṅgulam utsṛjya trīṇi trīṇi ca pārśvayoḥ
translated: Having left one finger from the root, and three on each side,

original: devayonis tu vijñeyā tatra mathyo hutāśanaḥ //
analyzed: devayoniḥ tu vijñeyā tatra mathyaḥ hutāśanaḥ
translated: The womb of the gods should be known, and the fire should be churned there.

original: mūlāt tyaktvāṅgulāny aṣṭau agrāt tu dvādaśaiva hi /
analyzed: mūlāt tyaktvā aṅgulāni aṣṭau agrāt tu dvādaśa eva hi
translated: Having left eight fingers from the root, and twelve from the tip,

original: antare devayoniḥ syāt tatra mathyo hutāśanaḥ //
analyzed: antare devayoniḥ syāt tatra mathyaḥ hutāśanaḥ
translated: In between should be the womb of the gods, and the fire should be churned there.

original: vedā yajñāya saṃbhūtā yajñā agnau pratiṣṭhitāḥ /
analyzed: vedāḥ yajñāya saṃbhūtāḥ yajñāḥ agnau pratiṣṭhitāḥ
translated: The Vedas are born for the sacrifice, the sacrifices are established in the fire.

original: araṇyor jāyate cāgnis tayos tasmāt pradhānatā //
analyzed: araṇyoḥ jāyate ca agniḥ tayoḥ tasmāt pradhāna tā
translated: The fire is born in the kindling woods, therefore they are the most important.

analyzed: araṇi ardhena ca eva syuḥ khādirau ca atrapīḍakau
translated: The kindling wood should be half the size, and the two churning sticks should be made of khadira wood.

original: netraṃ tu ṣaḍguṇaṃ cātrād uttaro 'ṣṭāṅgulaḥ smṛtaḥ //
analyzed: netram tu ṣaḍguṇam uttaraḥ ṣṭa aṅgulaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: The eye is six times the size, and the upper one is said to be eight fingers long.

original: aṣṭāṅgulaḥ pramanthaḥ syāc cātraṃ syād dvādaśāṅgulam /
analyzed: aṣṭa aṅgulaḥ pramanthaḥ syāt cātram syāt dvādaśa aṅgulam
translated: The churning stick should be eight fingers long, and the kindling wood should be twelve fingers long.

analyzed: ovīlī dvādaśa aṅgulā eṣa yajña vidhiḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: The ovilī is twelve fingers long, this is said to be the procedure for the sacrifice.

original: vyāmamantraṃ vadanty eke anye hastatrayaṃ viduḥ /
analyzed: vyāma mantram vadanti eke anye hasta trayam viduḥ
translated: Some say the vyāma mantra is three cubits long, others know it to be three handspans.

analyzed: trivṛtam muṣṭi saṃyuktam yajñavṛkṣa ja valkalaiḥ
translated: Covered with the bark of the sacrificial tree, with a fist.

original: cātre ca bhāskarāḥ proktā uttare vasavas tathā /
analyzed: cātre ca bhāskarāḥ proktāḥ uttare vasavaḥ tathā
translated: The sun is said to be in the kindling wood, and the Vasus in the upper one.

original: netre devagaṇāḥ sarve viṣṇuś caiva tu pīḍake //
analyzed: netre deva gaṇāḥ sarve viṣṇuḥ ca eva tu pīḍake
translated: All the groups of gods are in the eye, and Vishnu in the churning stick.

original: araṇir yā dvitīyā tu uttarā sā prakīrtitā /
analyzed: araṇiḥ yā dvitīyā tu uttarā sā prakīrtitā
translated: The second kindling wood is declared to be the upper one.

original: tatraikadeśaṃ saṃgṛhya uttaraḥ sa ca kīrtitaḥ //🔽prāṅmukhodaṅmukho vāpi bhrāmakaḥ paścimāmukhaḥ /
analyzed: tatra eka deśam saṃgṛhya uttaraḥ sa ca kīrtitaḥ  prāc mukha udak mukhaḥ vā api bhrāmakaḥ paścimā mukhaḥ
translated: Taking a part of that, the upper one is also declared.🔽Facing east or north, the churner faces west.

original: pāṇibhyāṃ pīḍanaṃ śubhram uttarāgraṃ pragṛhya tu //
analyzed: pāṇibhyām pīḍanam śubhram uttara agram pragṛhya tu
translated: Holding the upper end with the hands, the pressing is auspicious.

original: mūle mūlaṃ tu saṃyojya cātrasyaivottarasya ca /🔽araṇyupari saṃsthāpya pīḍakena tu pīḍayed //
analyzed: mūle mūlam tu saṃyojya ca atrasya eva uttarasya ca  araṇi upari saṃsthāpya pīḍakena tu pīḍayet
translated: Having joined the root of the churning stick to the root of the churning stick, and of the upper one,🔽placing it on the churning stick, one should press it with the pressing stick.

original: netreṇa bhrāmayec cātraṃ yāvad vahniḥ prajāyate /
analyzed: netreṇa bhrāmayet cātram yāvat vahniḥ prajāyate
translated: One should churn the churning stick with the eye until fire is produced.

original: sarvair hi devaiḥ saṃpannas tena sarvasukhaḥ smṛtaḥ //
analyzed: sarvaiḥ hi devaiḥ saṃpannaḥ tena sarva sukhaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: Endowed with all the gods, he is therefore remembered as the source of all happiness.

original: brahmādyair daivataiś caiva vidvadbhiś ca tapodhanaiḥ /
analyzed: brahma ādyaiḥ daivataiḥ ca eva vidvadbhiḥ ca tapodhanaiḥ
translated: By Brahma and other deities, and by learned ones rich in austerities,

analyzed: eṣa yantra prayogaḥ tu dṛṣṭaḥ yajña artha hetubhiḥ
translated: This application of the churning stick is seen by those who have seen the purpose of the sacrifice.

analyzed: yajamānena manthavyaḥ sva śākhā śrotriyeṇa vā
translated: The sacrificer should churn it, or one learned in his own branch of the Veda,

original: tanmantrena dvijāgryair vā smṛtam etad dhi manthanam //
analyzed: tad mantrena dvijāgryaiḥ vā smṛtam etat hi manthanam
translated: Or by the best of twice-born ones with those mantras. This churning is indeed remembered.

original: atha yady araṇī jīrṇe syātāṃ jantubhir manthanena vā //🔽samānīte nave araṇī āhṛtya śve bhūte darśenāṣṭvā tasmin pūrve śakalīkṛtya gārhapatye prakṣipyopary agnau dhārayan japati //
analyzed: atha yadi araṇī jīrṇe syātām jantubhiḥ manthanena vā  samānīte nave araṇī āhṛtya śve bhūte darśena aṣṭvā tasmin pūrve śakalīkṛtya gārhapatye prakṣipya upari agnau dhārayan japati
translated: Now if the churning sticks should become worn out by insects or by churning,🔽Having brought new churning sticks, having performed the Darsha sacrifice on the next day, having cut the old ones into pieces in that (sacrifice), having thrown them into the Garhapatya fire, holding them above the fire, he murmurs:

original: ud budhyasvāgne pra viśasya yonyāṃ devayajyāyai voḍhave jātavedaḥ /
analyzed: ud budhyasva agne pra viśasya yonyām deva yajyāyai voḍhave jātavedaḥ
translated: Awaken, O Agni, enter into your own womb for the sake of offering to the gods, O all-knower.

original: araṇyor araṇī saṃ carasva jīrṇāṃ tvacam ajīrṇayā nir ṇudasvety
analyzed: araṇyoḥ araṇī sam carasva jīrṇām tvacam a jīrṇayā niḥ nudasva iti
translated: Moving the two kindling woods together, remove the old skin with the new one.

analyzed: ājyam saṃskṛtya āhavanīye manasvatīm juhoti
translated: Having purified the ghee, he offers it in the Ahavaniya fire with the Manastuti hymn.

analyzed: putra arthī śrāvayet
translated: One desiring a son should recite it.

original: mano jyotir juṣatām ājyasya vichinnaṃ yajñaṃ sam imaṃ dadhātu /
analyzed: manaḥ jyotiḥ juṣatām ājyasya vichinnam yajñam sam imam dadhātu
translated: May the mind, the light, enjoy the ghee. May it unite this severed sacrifice.

original: yā iṣṭā uṣaso yā aniṣṭās tāḥ saṃ cinomi haviṣā ghṛtena svāheti agnaye 'gnimate 'ṣṭākapālaṃ puroḍāśaṃ nirvapati //
analyzed: yāḥ iṣṭāḥ uṣasaḥ yāḥ an iṣṭāḥ tāḥ sam cinomi haviṣā ghṛtena svāhā iti agnaye gnimate ṣṭākapālam puroḍāśam nirvapati
translated: The desired dawns and the undesired, I collect them with oblations of ghee, svāhā. He offers a cake on eight potsherds to Agni, the possessor of fire.

analyzed: śarau odanam sa dakṣiṇam dadāti
translated: He gives a rice dish in a pot with a gift.

analyzed: sā prakṛtā iṣtiḥ saṃgṛhyate
translated: That is the prescribed sacrifice, it is included.

analyzed: prasaṅgena eva kathitam agni manthanam atra vai
translated: The churning of the fire has been told here incidentally.

original: araṇyoś cāṅgasaṃbhūtaṃ netraṃ cātraṃ ca pīḍakaḥ //
analyzed: araṇyoḥ ca aṅga saṃbhūtam netram cātram ca pīḍakaḥ
translated: The eye born from the limbs of the kindling woods, the presser and the presser's staff.

original: ya idaṃ dhārayiṣyati araṇyor iha lakṣaṇam /
analyzed: yaḥ idam dhārayiṣyati araṇyoḥ iha lakṣaṇam
translated: He who will uphold this characteristic of the kindling woods here,

original: na tasya durlabhaṃ kiṃ cid loke paratra ca //
analyzed: na tasya durlabham kim cit loke paratra ca
translated: for him nothing is difficult to obtain in this world and in the next.

original: putrārthī śrāvayen nityam acirāl labhate sutam /
analyzed: putra arthī śrāvayet nityam acirāt labhate sutam
translated: One desiring a son should always recite it, he soon obtains a son,

analyzed: śruta śīlam vṛttavantam dīrgha āyuḥ vipulām prajām
translated: learned, virtuous, of good conduct, long-lived, and abundant offspring.

analyzed: etat evam samākhyātam pippalādena dhīmatā
translated: This has been thus declared by the wise Pippalāda,

analyzed: dvijānām bāla vṛddhānām puraścaraṇam uttamam
translated: For twice-born people, the best expiation is for the young and the old.

analyzed: adhītya etat ca dehānte param brahma adhigacchati
translated: Having studied this, at the end of the body, he attains the supreme Brahman.

original: na tasya mṛtyur na jarā nidrā vyādhir na caiva hi /
analyzed: na tasya mṛtyuḥ na jarā nidrā vyādhiḥ na ca eva hi
translated: He has no death, no old age, no sleep, and no disease.

analyzed: kṣudh pipāsā bhayam na asti brahma bhūtaḥ sa tiṣṭhati
translated: There is no fear of hunger, thirst, or want, he abides as one who has become Brahman.

analyzed: yajña pātra lakṣaṇam
translated: The Characteristics of the Sacrificial Utensils

original: om athāto yajñapātrāṇāṃ lakṣaṇaṃ yonir eva ca /
analyzed: om atha atas yajña pātrāṇām lakṣaṇam yoniḥ eva ca
translated: Om. Now, the characteristics of the sacrificial vessels and their origins,

original: rūpaṃ tathā pramāṇaṃ ca kramenaiva prakathyate //
analyzed: rūpam tathā pramāṇam ca kramena eva prakathyate
translated: their form and measure are described in order.

analyzed: camasa graha pātrāṇi homa pātrāṇi yāni ca
translated: The sacrificial ladles, the vessels for holding Soma, the vessels for oblations,

analyzed: yajña vṛkṣāḥ tathā śākhāḥ brahmavede pradarśitāḥ
translated: the sacrificial trees and branches are shown in the Vedas of the Brahmins.

analyzed: pitṛ piṇḍeṣu darvī ādyam agniṣvāttam ca yājñikam
translated: In the offerings to the ancestors, the ladle and other implements, and the sacrificial implements for the fire oblations,

original: sāyaṃhomeṣu nityāni tathā naimittikāni ca //🔽bilvākṛtiś caruḥ proktas tāmro vā mṛnmayo 'pi vā /
analyzed: sāyaṃhomeṣu nityāni tathā naimittikāni ca  bilva ākṛtiḥ caruḥ proktaḥ tāmraḥ vā vā
translated: the regular daily offerings in the evening oblations, and the occasional ones,🔽the sacrificial porridge is said to be shaped like a bilva fruit, either copper or earthen,

analyzed: grīvāyām mukha vistīrṇaḥ carusthālī iti kīrttitaḥ
translated: with a neck as wide as the mouth, it is called the porridge pot.

original: kuśasyāmrasya vā parṇair veṇor vā balbajasya vā /
analyzed: kuśasya āmrasya vā parṇaiḥ veṇoḥ vā balbajasya vā
translated: With leaves of kusha grass, mango tree, bamboo, or balbaja grass,

original: catuṣkoṇārdhavītaṃ ca loke śūrpaṃ tad ucyate //
analyzed: catuṣkoṇa ardha vītam ca loke śūrpam tat ucyate
translated: the winnowing basket in the world is said to be half-covered in the four corners.

original: asiḥ khaḍgaṃ ca nistriṃśaḥ paryāyāḥ parikīrttitāḥ /
analyzed: asiḥ khaḍgam ca nistriṃśaḥ paryāyāḥ parikīrttitāḥ
translated: Sword, scimitar, and saber are mentioned as synonyms.

original: tadākṛṭy eva yad rūpaṃ yajñe sphyaṃ ca vadanti tam //🔽idhmocchrayam ardhakhātaṃ khātenaiva tu vistaraḥ /🔽madhye hīnaṃ tathordhvāgraṃ vāraṇaṃ tad ulūkhalam //
analyzed: tad ākṛṭi eva yat rūpam yajñe sphyam ca vadanti tam  idhma ucchrayam ardha khātam khātena eva tu vistaraḥ  madhye hīnam tathā ūrdhva agram vāraṇam tat ulūkhalam
translated: The form that is made from that is called the sacrificial post.🔽The sacrificial post should be half-buried, with the same width as the hole.🔽It should be smaller in the middle and have a tip above, that is the mortar.

analyzed: sthūla tvāt muṣṭi mātram ca skandha mātram pramāṇataḥ
translated: Due to its thickness, it should be the size of a fist, and the size of a shoulder.

original: vāraṇaṃ musalaṃ caiva adhastāl lohaveṣṭitam //🔽sruvas tu mūladaṇḍaś ca bilaṃ cāṅguṣṭhaparvaṇaḥ /
analyzed: vāraṇam musalam ca eva adhastāt loha veṣṭitam  sruvaḥ tu mūla daṇḍaḥ ca bilam ca aṅguṣṭha parvaṇaḥ
translated: The pestle should be made of iron below.🔽The ladle should have a handle at the base, and a hole the size of the thumb joint.

analyzed: samavete pṛthak bhūte bila ardhe daṇḍa vṛtta tā
translated: When joined, the hole should be half the circumference of the handle.

original: vaikaṅkatī dhruvā proktā sarvayajñeṣu yā smṛtā /
analyzed: vaikaṅkatī dhruvā proktā sarva yajñeṣu yā smṛtā
translated: The sacrificial ladle is said to be made of Vibhitaka wood, which is used in all sacrifices.

analyzed: tathā agnihotrahavaṇī sruvaḥ ca api tathā smṛtaḥ
translated: Similarly, the ladle for Agnihotra and the sacrificial ladle are also remembered.

analyzed: mūla daṇḍā tvac bilā ca puṣkaram catur aṅgulam
translated: The handle at the base, the bark, and the hole should be four finger-breadths.

analyzed: puṣkarāt dviguṇam ca agram gajoṣṭham paripaṭhyate
translated: The tip should be twice the size of the hole, and is said to be like an elephant's trunk.

analyzed: netra ādi karaṇaiḥ hīnam nāsikābhyām dvijaiḥ tathā
translated: It should be without eyes and other sense organs, and without nostrils, by the twice-born.

original: dvyaṅgulaḥ khātā ca bilād aṅgulaṃ caiva piṇḍikā /
analyzed: dvi aṅgulaḥ khātā ca bilāt aṅgulam ca eva piṇḍikā
translated: The hole should be two finger-breadths deep from the hole, and the pedestal should be one finger-breadth.

original: vṛttā vā caturaśrā vā sādhastāc chobhanā smṛtā //🔽ardhāṅgulaṃ pṛthutvena bilabāhyaṃ samantataḥ /
analyzed: vṛttā vā caturaśrā vā sā adhastāt śobhanā smṛtā  ardha aṅgulam pṛthu tvena bila bāhyam samantataḥ
translated: It is considered auspicious if it is circular or square at the bottom.🔽The hole outside the ladle should be half an aṅgula in width all around.

original: bilaṃ vṛttaṃ sruco madhye daṇḍasthaulyaṃ bilārdhataḥ //
analyzed: bilam vṛttam srucaḥ madhye daṇḍa sthaulyam bila ardhataḥ
translated: The hole in the middle of the ladle should be round, and the handle should be half the thickness of the hole.

analyzed: caturviṃśati aṅgulam daṇḍam vadanti eke manīṣiṇaḥ
translated: Some wise men say that the handle should be twenty-four aṅgulas long.

original: saptatriṃśad aṅgulāni sā sruk caiva prakīrtitā //
analyzed: saptatriṃśat aṅgulāni sā sruc ca eva prakīrtitā
translated: It is declared that the ladle should be thirty-seven aṅgulas long.

original: bhinnā viśīrṇā vakrā ca klinnā ca sphuṭitā tathā /🔽suṣirā granthibhir yuktā cakṣurādivināśinī //
analyzed: bhinnā viśīrṇā vakrā ca klinnā ca sphuṭitā tathā  suṣirā granthibhiḥ yuktā cakṣuḥ ādi vināśinī
translated: If it is broken, cracked, crooked, wet, split,🔽full of holes, or knotted, it destroys the eyes and other sense organs.

analyzed: dagdha śeṣe ṛdha śuṣke ca vidyutā ca eva pātite
translated: If it is burnt, half-dry, struck by lightning,

original: unmūlye patite bhagne manasāpi na cintayet //
analyzed: unmūlye patite bhagne manasā api na cintayet
translated: uprooted, fallen, or broken, one should not even think of it.

analyzed: śubha nakṣatra atithiṣu śubhām gatvā diśam budhaḥ
translated: On auspicious lunar days and under auspicious constellations, the wise one should go to an auspicious direction,

original: sruvārthaṃ pātayed vṛkṣaṃ prātaḥ prāgraṃ ca saumyavāk //
analyzed: sruva artham pātayet vṛkṣam prātar prāgram ca saumya vāc
translated: and in the morning, with a gentle voice, he should fell a tree for the sacrificial ladle, with the top pointing east.

analyzed: mṛgaḥ hariṇa ruruḥ ca kṛṣṇa pṛṣṭha śiraḥ tathā
translated: A deer, a spotted deer, a ruru deer, and a black-backed and black-headed deer,

original: yat tasya carma tvak caiva tat kṛṣṇājinam ucyate //
analyzed: yat tasya carma tvac ca eva tat kṛṣṇājinam ucyate
translated: the skin and hide of which are called the black antelope skin.

analyzed: vāma muṣṭi gṛhītāḥ tu prachidyante sakṛt kuśāḥ
translated: The kuśa grass is cut once, held in the left fist,

original: paraśunāsinā vā tat sakṛdāchinnam ucyate //🔽aṅguṣṭhaparvāgramukhaṃ darvyākṛti tu mekṣaṇam / vaikaṅkate pālāśe vā prādeśas tu pramāṇataḥ //
analyzed: paraśunā asinā vā tat sakṛdāchinnam ucyate  aṅguṣṭha parva agra mukham darvī ākṛti tu mekṣaṇam vaikaṅkate pālāśe vā prādeśaḥ tu pramāṇataḥ
translated: That is said to be cut once with an axe or a knife.🔽The corn-stirring stick is shaped like a ladle, with the tip of the thumb as the mouth, and is four finger-breadths in size.

original: alābu vaiṇavaṃ vāpi dārvyaṃ vaiṇavam eva vā /
analyzed: alābu vaiṇavam vā api dārvyam vaiṇavam eva vā
translated: It is made of Vibhitaka wood or Palasha wood, and is four finger-breadths in size.

original: akṣāv amaṇḍalau proktau yathā dṛṣṭaṃ pura rṣibhiḥ //🔽cakrābhyāṃ kāṣṭhasaṃghātaiḥ śilpibhiś caiva yat kṛtam /
analyzed: akṣau a maṇḍalau proktau yathā dṛṣṭam pura ṛṣibhiḥ  cakrābhyām kāṣṭha saṃghātaiḥ śilpibhiḥ ca eva yat kṛtam
translated: The two dice are said to be without circles, as seen by the ancient sages.🔽The cart is well-known in the world, made by craftsmen with wheels, bundles of wood, and so on.

original: loke prasiddhaṃ śakaṭam agniṣṭhaṃ yājñike vidhau //
analyzed: loke prasiddham śakaṭam agniṣṭham yājñike vidhau
translated: In the sacrificial ritual, it is called the sacrificial post.

analyzed: ājyam ghṛtam vijānīyāt navanītam susaṃskṛtam
translated: Clarified butter should be known as ghee, well-prepared fresh butter.

original: sauvīrādy añjanaṃ caiva atha vā daivikaṃ tathā //🔽abhyañjanaṃ ca tat praktaṃ tilatailaṃ ca yad viduḥ /
analyzed: sauvīra ādi añjanam ca eva atha vā daivikam tathā  abhyañjanam ca tat praktam tila tailam ca yat viduḥ
translated: Sauvira and other collyriums, or the divine one,🔽And the anointing well-known as done with sesame oil.

analyzed: āsanam kaśipu proktam kāyastham ca upabarhaṇam
translated: A seat is said to be a mat, and a pillow is a support for the body.

analyzed: yavodaraiḥ aṣṭabhiḥ tu aṅgulam paripaṭhyate
translated: Eight barley grains are said to be one finger-breadth.

analyzed: caru tviṃśati aṅgulam tu yājñikaiḥ hastaḥ ākṛtaḥ
translated: The sacrificial experts have defined a cubit as twenty-four finger-breadths.

original: hastamātraṃ sruvaḥ khaḍgaṃ sakṛdāchinnam eva ca /
analyzed: hasta mātram sruvaḥ khaḍgam sakṛdāchinnam eva ca
translated: The sacrificial ladle is one cubit long, the knife is cut once,

original: bāhumātrā juhūḥ proktā dhruvā barhis tathaiva ca //
analyzed: bāhu mātrā juhūḥ proktā dhruvā barhiḥ tathā eva ca
translated: The Juhu ladle is said to be of the length of a forearm, and so are the Dhruva and the sacrificial grass.

original: tāmraś caiva sruvaḥ proktaḥ khaḍgaṃ khādiram eva ca /
analyzed: tāmraḥ ca eva sruvaḥ proktaḥ khaḍgam khādiram eva ca
translated: The Sruva ladle is said to be made of copper, and the sacrificial knife is made of Khadira wood.

original: pālāśī ca juhūḥ kāryā idhmāś caiva viśeṣataḥ //🔽grahāḥ pātrāṇi camasā daṇḍayūpāsanāni ca /
analyzed: pālāśī ca juhūḥ kāryā idhmāḥ ca eva viśeṣataḥ  grahāḥ pātrāṇi camasāḥ daṇḍa yūpa asanāni ca
translated: The Juhu ladle should be made of Palasha wood, and the sacrificial fuel should be especially of that wood.

analyzed: vṛkṣeṣu yājñikeṣu syuḥ yathā lābheṣu na anyatas
translated: The sacrificial vessels, ladles, sacrificial posts, and seats should be made of sacrificial trees, as available, and not from any other trees.

analyzed: samidhaḥ prādeśa mātryaḥ nitya home prakīrtitāḥ
translated: Fuel sticks of the size of a span are prescribed for daily oblations.

original: samillakṣaṇadṛṣṭāni pramāṇāni yathākramam //🔽śamy aśvatthaḥ palāśaś ca khādiro 'tha vikaṅkataḥ /
analyzed: samidh lakṣaṇa dṛṣṭāni pramāṇāni yathākramam  śamī aśvatthaḥ palāśaḥ ca vikaṅkataḥ
translated: The measurements are seen to be according to the characteristics of the fuel sticks.🔽The sacrificial trees are declared to be the Sami, Ashvattha, Palasha, Khadira, Vikankata,
Kashmari, Udumbara, and Bilva.

original: eṣām alābhe vṛkṣāṇām anye grāhyās tu yājñikaiḥ /
analyzed: eṣām alābhe vṛkṣāṇām anye grāhyāḥ tu yājñikaiḥ
translated: In the absence of these trees, others may be used by those performing sacrifices.

analyzed: yajña aṅga kārye draṣṭavyāḥ samidh artham viśeṣataḥ
translated: They should be considered especially for the purpose of fuel in the performance of sacrificial rites.

analyzed: yava vrīhi mahāvrīhi prayaṅgūṇām hi taṇḍulāḥ
translated: The grains of barley, rice, large rice, and millet,

analyzed: śyāmāka taṇḍula tilāḥ āsādyāḥ śruti coditāḥ
translated: and the rice grains of Shyamaka and sesame are to be procured as prescribed by the Vedas.

original: sāyaṃhomeṣu yad dravyaṃ prātarhomeṣu tad bhavet /
analyzed: sāyaṃhomeṣu yat dravyam prātar homeṣu tat bhavet
translated: The substances used in the evening oblations should be used in the morning oblations as well.

original: bhinnadravyahutaṃ yat tu na hutaṃ tasya tad bhavet //
analyzed: bhinna dravya hutam yat tu na hutam tasya tat bhavet
translated: But what is offered in a broken vessel is not considered as offered by him.

analyzed: udite n udite ca eva samayādhyuṣite tathā
translated: When the sun has risen, not risen, when it is time for the vow,

original: kṣudhākāle tathāpy keke pakṣahomaṃ tu kārayet //
analyzed: kṣudhā kāle tathā api keke pakṣa homam tu kārayet
translated: and also when it is time for hunger, one should perform the monthly sacrifice.

original: yāyāvarāṇāṃ munibhiḥ pakṣahomas tu taiḥ smṛtaḥ /
analyzed: yāyāvarāṇām munibhiḥ pakṣa homaḥ tu taiḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: The monthly sacrifice is remembered by the sages of the Yāyāvarīya school.

original: yathā kathaṃ cid vacanaṃ śrutyuktaṃ dvija ācāret //
analyzed: yathā katham cit vacanam śruti uktam dvijaḥ ācāret
translated: A twice-born should perform the sacrifice in any way, as stated in the Veda.

original: āturaḥ pathikaś caiva rājopadravapīḍitaḥ /🔽pakṣahomaṃ tadā kuryān nistīrya satataṃ caret //
analyzed: āturaḥ pathikaḥ ca eva rāja upadrava pīḍitaḥ  pakṣa homam tadā kuryāt nistīrya satatam caret
translated: One who is sick, a traveler, one afflicted by royal oppression,🔽should perform the monthly sacrifice then, and when he has passed beyond, he should always perform it.

analyzed: caturdaśa gṛhītam tu sakṛt unnayate haviḥ
translated: Taking fourteen times, he offers the oblation once.

original: ekā samit sakṛd dhomaḥ so 'rdhamāsāya kalpate //
analyzed: ekā samidh sakṛt homaḥ saḥ ṛdh māsāya kalpate
translated: One kindling-stick, one oblation, that is prescribed for half a month.

analyzed: caturdaśaguṇam kṛtvā srucā pātreṇa pūrvavat
translated: Having multiplied by fourteen, with the ladle as before,

original: evaṃ gārhapatye ca dakṣiṇāgnau ca juhvati //
analyzed: evam gārhapatye ca dakṣiṇāgnau ca juhvati
translated: in the same way they offer in the Gārhapatya and Dakṣiṇāgni.

analyzed: pūrvāḥ hutvā āhutīḥ sāyam vyuṣṭāyām apare hni
translated: Having offered the morning oblations in the evening, after dawn on the next day,

original: etenaiva vidhānena juhvati prātarāhutīḥ //🔽ṛṣibhiś ca purā dṛṣṭam āpatkāleṣu sarvataḥ /
analyzed: etena eva vidhānena juhvati prātarāhutīḥ  ṛṣibhiḥ ca purā dṛṣṭam āpad kāleṣu sarvatas
translated: in the same manner they offer the morning oblations.🔽And seen by the sages of old in all calamities,

analyzed: araṇyoḥ ca samāropya śruti dṛṣṭena karmaṇā
translated: having consigned the sacred fires to the kindling woods, by the rite seen in the Śruti,

analyzed: homa artheṣu etat draṣṭavyam āhitāgni gṛheṣu api
translated: This should be seen in the case of oblations, even in the houses of those who have installed the sacred fires.

original: tatprayojanamātraṃ tu na doṣaḥ sūtakeṣu ca //
analyzed: tad prayojana mātram tu na doṣaḥ sūtakeṣu ca
translated: But the mere purpose of that is not a fault in the case of impurity.

analyzed: sadyaḥśauca ādikam proktam sūtakam ca dvijātibhiḥ
translated: The immediate purification etc. is declared by the twice-born ones to be the impurity.

analyzed: svayaṃhomī iti vacanāt na doṣaḥ śruti codanāt
translated: Due to the statement one should offer oblations oneself and because of the injunction of the Vedas, there is no fault.

original: vratināṃ sattriṇāṃ caiva mahārājāhitāgnayaḥ /🔽eṣāṃ doṣo na vidyeta sāyamprātaḥ kriye sthite //
analyzed: vratinām sattriṇām ca eva mahā rāja āhitāgnayaḥ  eṣām doṣaḥ na vidyeta sāyamprātar kriye sthite
translated: For those who are observing vows, those who are performing sacrifices, and the great kings who have installed the sacred fires,🔽there is no fault for them if they perform the evening and morning rites.

analyzed: pālāśyaḥ samidhaḥ doṣāḥ nityam home prakīrtitāḥ
translated: Palāśa kindling sticks are declared to be faultless in daily oblations.

analyzed: atha vā kauśika uktānām yajñiyānām mahīruhām
translated: Or, of the sacrificial trees mentioned by Kauśika,

analyzed: aṅgula trayam āvartya ucchraye pi aṅgula trayam
translated: having a circumference of three finger-breadths, and a height of three finger-breadths,

analyzed: puroḍāśa pramāṇam tu sarvatra kathitam nṛṇām
translated: the size of the sacrificial cakes is declared everywhere for men.

analyzed: ṣoḍaśa aṅgulam āvartya tri bhāgam ca uttaram ṛju
translated: Having a circumference of sixteen finger-breadths, and a height of three parts, straight,

analyzed: dakṣiṇasyām diśi sthānam dakṣiṇāgneḥ prakīrtitam
translated: the place in the southern direction is declared to be for the Dakṣiṇāgni.

analyzed: aṣṭāviṃśati aṅgulāni gārhapatyam prakīrtitam
translated: Twenty-eight finger-breadths is declared to be the size of the Gārhapatya fire.

analyzed: āhavanīyam caturviṃśatiḥ catur aśram tu kārayet
translated: One should make the Āhavanīya fire twenty-four finger-breadths and square.

original: aṅgulāni tu ṣaṭtriṃśad dhnvākṛtyā tu kārayet /🔽dakṣiṇāgnes tu vai kuṇḍaṃ vidvadbhij parikathyate //
analyzed: aṅgulāni tu ṣaṭtriṃśat tu kārayet  dakṣiṇāgneḥ tu vai kuṇḍam vidvadbhiḥ parikathyate
translated: The dimensions should be thirty-six finger-breadths, with the shape of a bow.🔽The pit for the Dakshina fire is said to be circular by the learned.

analyzed: īśānyām diśi sabhyasya gārhapatya vidhānataḥ
translated: In the northeast direction, for the Sabhya fire, according to the Garhapatya procedure.

original: sabhyaṃ necchanti śālāgnau māhakiḥ kauśikas tathā //
analyzed: sabhyam na icchanti śālāgnau māhakiḥ kauśikaḥ tathā
translated: Mahakali and Kaushika do not desire the Sabhya fire in the Shala fire.

analyzed: maudāyanāḥ tathā icchanti śaunakeyāḥ tathā eva ca
translated: Maudayana and Shaunakeya desire it in the same way.

original: mantād eva tathā proktaṃ dravyaṃ yatra na dṛśyate //
analyzed: mantāt eva tathā proktam dravyam yatra na dṛśyate
translated: It is said that where the substance is not seen,

original: ājyaṃ tatra vijānīiyād dhomas tatra sruveṇa ca /🔽abhyukṣaṇaṃ haviḥkarma kartavyaṃ vajrapāṇinā //
analyzed: ājyam tatra vijānīyāt homaḥ tatra sruveṇa ca  abhyukṣaṇam haviḥ karma kartavyam vajrapāṇinā
translated: there the offering should be known to be with ghee and the oblation should be with the sacrificial ladle.🔽The sprinkling of the sacrificial material should be done by the wielder of the thunderbolt.

analyzed: kuśa hastena kartavyāḥ japa homa pitṛ kriyāḥ
translated: The muttering of mantras, oblations, and rites for the manes should be done with the hand holding kusha grass.

analyzed: yajñe ca eva aṅga bhūtāḥ ca pātra mantra haviḥ dvijāḥ
translated: The vessels, mantras, sacrificial offerings, and the twice-born are the auxiliaries in a sacrifice.

original: carutbhiś ca kriyāḥ sarvāś cāturhotraṃ tad ucyate //
analyzed: carutbhiḥ ca kriyāḥ sarvāḥ cāturhotram tat ucyate
translated: And all the rites with the metres are called the fourfold sacrificial session.

original: yājñikās tu vadanty anye caturbhir yac ca hūyate /
analyzed: yājñikāḥ tu vadanti anye caturbhiḥ yat ca hūyate
translated: But other sacrificers say that which is offered with the four,

analyzed: brahmaṇā adhvaryu hotṛbhyām tribhiḥ agni caturthakaiḥ
translated: with Brahma, Adhvaryu, Hotri, and the three with Agni as the fourth.

original: durbhikṣe cākule bhaṅge ṛtvijāṃ cāpy asaṃbhave /
analyzed: durbhikṣe ca ākule bhaṅge ṛtvijām ca api asaṃbhave
translated: In times of famine, confusion, and the impossibility of the officiating priests,

original: ekaś cāturhotraṃ kuryād āpastambe prapaṭhyate //🔽ṛtvijāṃ asāmnidhye adhvaryus tat paṭhet svayam /
analyzed: ekaḥ cāturhotram kuryāt āpastambe prapaṭhyate  ṛtvijām a sāmnidhye adhvaryuḥ tat paṭhet svayam
translated: And one may perform the fourfold Hotr duties, as recited by Apastamba.🔽If the priests are not present, the Adhvaryu should recite it himself.

analyzed: a sthāna paṭhite kuryuḥ ṛtvij ityādi ca uditam
translated: If it is not recited in the proper place, they should do it, as enjoined by the statement the priests, etc.

original: khāte lūne tu yac coktaṃ saṃskāraśrutihetubhiḥ /
analyzed: khāte lūne tu yat ca uktam saṃskāra śruti hetubhiḥ
translated: And what is said about the dug-up and cut-off, by the causes of the Vedic injunctions for purification,

original: dravyāṇāṃ yajñakLptyarthaṃ kuryāt pūrveṇa saṃgraham //🔽pātrāsādaṃ dvitīyaṃ ca prokṣaṇena vivarjitam /
analyzed: dravyāṇām yajña klpti artham kuryāt pūrveṇa saṃgraham  pātra āsādam dvitīyam ca prokṣaṇena vivarjitam
translated: For the purpose of the sacrificial equipment of the substances, one should make the collection with the previous one.

analyzed: ubhayoḥ ca eva kurvīta pākayajña iṣṭi karma vat
translated: The second, which is without sprinkling, should be done for both, like the sacrificial rite of the domestic fire.

original: kṛṣṇājinaṃ tilā darbhā mantrā ājyaṃ dvijottamāḥ /
analyzed: kṛṣṇājinam tilāḥ darbhāḥ mantrāḥ ājyam dvijottamāḥ
translated: The black antelope skin, sesamum seeds, darbha grass, mantras, clarified butter, and best of twice-born ones,

original: doṣo na vidyate hy eṣāṃ yathārthaṃ saṃniyojayet //
analyzed: doṣaḥ na vidyate hi eṣām yathārtham saṃniyojayet
translated: These have no fault, one should employ them according to their meaning.

analyzed: ājyam dhūma haviḥ jvālā paripākaḥ sphuliṅgakaiḥ
translated: Clarified butter, smoke, oblation, flame, and sparks,

analyzed: dāva agni kāṣṭha saṃsparśe agneḥ doṣaḥ na vidyate
translated: When in contact with forest fire and wood, there is no fault of the fire.

analyzed: japa adhyāya tapaḥ dānaiḥ sa upavāsaiḥ sa homakaiḥ
translated: By muttering, studying, austerities, giving, along with fasting and oblations,

analyzed: śrāddha ādi pitṛ kāryaiḥ ca na doṣaḥ parivedane
translated: And by Śrāddha and other rites for the manes, there is no fault in changing the fire.

analyzed: pitṛ bhrātṛ sapatnaiḥ ca patita unmatta ṣaṇḍhakaiḥ
translated: By the manes, brothers, enemies, fallen, insane, eunuchs,

analyzed: jātyandha mūka badhiraiḥ na doṣaḥ parivedane
translated: There is no fault in the Pariveda (change of Veda) by one who is born blind, dumb, or deaf,

analyzed: atyanta kāminā ca eva patnī hīnena ca eva hi
translated: And by one who is extremely lustful, and by one who is without a wife.

original: eṣām anujñām ādāya kuryād vaitānikīḥ kriyāḥ //
analyzed: eṣām anujñām ādāya kuryāt vaitānikīḥ kriyāḥ
translated: Having obtained permission from them, one should perform the Vedic rites.

analyzed: raudra rākṣasa paiśācān āsurān ca ābhicārikān
translated: The Rudra, Rakshasa, Paisacha, Asura, and Abhichara rites,

analyzed: ca pitṛ karma evam kṛtvā ālabhya udakam spṛśet
translated: And the rites for the ancestors, having done thus, one should touch water.

original: sruk sruvaś ca dhruvā khaḍgaṃ musalolūkhalaṃ caruḥ /

analyzed: guruṇā bhāṣitena eva yājñika anumatena ca

Emitting the fragrance of lotus stalks, lotuses, durva grass, and lilies,

The fire, with a mass of united flames, destroys sins.
The color of a kurunta bird, cow's milk, gold, or a reddish lightning flash,
Shining like a fully blossomed blue lotus, jasmine, moon, or white lotus.

translated: The fire to be worshipped, worshipped by the king.🔽And due to the arrangement of the spread, the sacrificial implements,

translated: Where the fire god, the giver of prosperity, is white like a lotus stalk, with a smooth and round flame,

analyzed: vaiśvānaraḥ jvalati yasya viśuddha mūrtiḥ sa prāpnuyāt nṛpa śata adhipa tām narendraḥ
translated: The king, with a pure form, may attain the lordship of a hundred kings.

analyzed: bāla arka bodhita saroruha garbha gandhaḥ toya avalambi jalada stanita abhirāmaḥ
translated: The fire god, with the fragrance of lotus buds awakened by the rising sun, with the sound of clouds clinging to the water,

analyzed: rājñaḥ dadāti vasudhām hutabhuj gaja indra danta agra kampita mahā arṇava vīci vṛkṣām
translated: Gives the earth to the king, with the waves of the great ocean trembling at the tips of the tusks of the lord of elephants.

original: yasyāṃ vasantaravimaṇḍalatulyabimbo vedyāṃ nṛpasya paripūrṇamarīcijālaḥ /🔽tasyānalākalitasāgaratoyavastrā mrāgaikṣavenir avanir vaśam abhyupaiti //🔽yasyānalo jvalati kāñcanatulyagauro prajvālyamānavapur utpalakośagandhaḥ /

translated: On which, in the sacrificial arena of the king, with a form equal to the orb of the spring sun, with a net of full rays,🔽The earth, with the garment of the waters of the ocean tossed by the fire, goes under the control of the king, with the garland of bees.🔽The fire god, with a body burning like gold, with the fragrance of a lotus bud,

original: āyāti tasya bhavanaṃ hy alidīptimālā savrīḍasūryakiraṇā kṣitipālalakṣmīr iti //
analyzed: āyāti tasya bhavanam hi ali dīpti mālā sa vrīḍa sūrya kiraṇā kṣitipāla lakṣmīḥ iti
translated: The prosperity of the king, with the garland of bees, with the rays of the shy sun, comes to his house.

analyzed: kuṇḍa lakṣaṇam
translated: The Characteristics of a Fire Pit

original: oṃ śaunakaṃ tu sukhāsīnaṃ bhārgavaḥ paripṛcchati /
analyzed: om śaunakam tu sukha āsīnam bhārgavaḥ paripṛcchati
translated: Om. Bhargava asks Shaunaka, who is comfortably seated,

original: kuṇḍaṃ kasmin bhavet kīdṛk kasyāṃ vā diśi kiṃ phalam //🔽sa tasmā upasannāya ācaṣṭe bhārgavāya tu /
analyzed: kuṇḍam kasmin bhavet kīdṛś kasyām vā diśi kim phalam  sa tasmai upasannāya ācaṣṭe bhārgavāya tu
translated: In which direction should the sacrificial pit be? What should it be like? What are its fruits?

analyzed: kuṇḍam yasmin bhavet yādṛś yasyām vā diśi yat phalam
translated: He tells him, The sacrificial pit should be in such and such a direction, it should be of such and such a form, and it has such and such fruits.

analyzed: caturaśram śapha ākṛtyāḥ ardha candram tri koṇakam
translated: A square pit, a pit shaped like a hoof, a half-moon pit, a triangular pit,

analyzed: vartulam pañca koṇam ca padma ābham sapta koṇakam
translated: A round pit, a five-sided pit, a lotus-shaped pit, and a seven-sided pit.
These pits should be indicated in the eight directions starting from the east.

analyzed: digdevatānām ca aṣṭānām karmaṇi svam svam ādiśet
translated: For the rites of the eight directional deities, each one should be indicated in its own direction.

original: caturaśraṃ tu pūrvasyām aindreṣv api ca karmasu /🔽śaphākṛti tadāgneyyām āgneyeṣv api karmasu //
analyzed: caturaśram tu pūrvasyām aindreṣu api ca karmasu  śapha ākṛti tat āgneyyām āgneyeṣu api karmasu
translated: In the east, a square pit should be used, and also for rites related to Indra.🔽In the southeast, a pit shaped like a hoof should be used, and also for rites related to Agni.

original: ardhacandraṃ tu yāmyāyāṃ yāmyeṣv api ca karmasu /
analyzed: ardhacandram tu yāmyāyām yāmyeṣu api ca karmasu
translated: In the south, a half-moon shaped pit should be used, and also for rites related to Yama.

original: nairṛtyāṃ ca trikoṇaṃ syād abhicāravidhau śubham //🔽vāruṇyāṃ vartulaṃ jñeyaṃ vāruṇyeṣv api karmasu /
